Despite the advantages of zeolite catalysts/carriers, the small pore size of HY zeolite causes diffusion limitations especially for bulky refractory sulfur compounds in oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of fuels. To overcome this restriction, extruded HY-zeolite/Alumina composites containing both micro and meso‑pores were successfully synthesized and used as an attractive carrier for the vanadium dispersion. Insights about the interactions between zeolite and alumina and their effects on the vanadium impregnation were given implementing different analysis approaches; BET, SEM-EDX, TEM, NH3-TPD, and UV-vis. Alumina particle piling created meso‑pores in the composites providing a positive impact on the ODS of bulky dibenzothiophene (DBT). Comparing to physical mixing of the alumina and zeolite, the extrusion approach notably enhanced the weak acid sites due to the removal/distorting tetrahedrally coordinated Al from the zeolite framework. A less increase in the strong acid sites was also resulted from the reaction of Al-OH in the alumina with the free Si-OH over the zeolite. The proposed catalyst (V/HYZ-Al(alumina/zeolite ratio=50%) exhibited an excellent DBT removal so that 1000 ppmw of DBT was eliminated completely under the optimal investigated conditions (T = 50 °C, O/(S+N)=12 mol/mol, time=90 min, Mcatalyst/Vfuel=10 g/L). The catalyst recyclability was proved to be acceptable during four examined successive ODS cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords HY zeolite Alumina Extrusion Composite Oxidative desulfurization Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The lowest sulfur content of liquid fuels determined by the European Union in recent years indicates the importance of the development and improvement of deep desulfurization processes [1]. Reducing the amount of sulfur content in the liquid fuels to less than 10 ppm by conventional hydrodesulfurization (HDS) requires severe operating conditions and high investment and operating costs [2]. Oxidative desulfurization (ODS) as a non-hydrotreating process can be performed under mild conditions, atmospheric pressure and temperature lower than 100 °C without any expensive hydrogen [3–6]. In recent years, ODS draws widespread attention as a promising method for deep desulfurization of refractory compounds which need hard operating conditions in the HDS. Different transition metals in the high oxidation states and a high Lewis acidity (Ti, Fe, V, W, and Mo) supported on porous materials, are known as attractive catalysts from the economic point of view in the ODS process. Binary composites of titania-silica [7–9], titania-alumina [10], alumina-silica [11], zeolites [3,12], mesoporous materials [4,13–17] and metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [18], have been suggested as more appropriated supports for the transition metal catalysts in the previous ODS research studies. Noteworthy, HY zeolite has been considered as an efficient support due to its characteristic features such as high thermal stability, high surface area, large pore volume, and strong Bronsted and Lewis acid sites. However, the small pore size of this zeolite causes serious diffusion limitations especially for removal of bulky refractory sulfur compounds [3,12,19,20]. Hierarchical zeolites containing both micro and meso pores were introduced to overcome the mentioned restrictions [21–24]. In order to produce a hierarchical structure, a selective removal of aluminum or silica in the presence of hard/soft templates during the zeolite synthesis has been extensively studied [25]. However, these methods have some drawbacks such as partial failure of the structure, loss of the acidic sites, limited industrial application, and increase the production costs. Besides, most of the used templates are not commercially available. One of the most studied approaches for enhancing the zeolites structure, is the preparation of hybrid matrix applying another compound, especially metal oxides, i.e. Al2O3, SiO2, natural clay, in the zeolite structure [2,26]. This approach may provide a combination of favorite properties of two components and can offer a promising method for employing zeolites in deep desulfurization. With this approach, the porosity of the zeolite structure can be adjusted [27]. In addition, the acidity of the final catalyst can be significantly influenced by the chemical interaction formed between the zeolite and metal oxides [28]. The method applied for the preparation of hybrid matrix is very important because the interaction between different components can be highly influenced by the used approach. There are two main strategies for combining the zeolite with other conventional supports; (1) preparation of composites through sol-gel method [29]. (2) preparation of composites through mechanically mixing [1,30–33]. For example, Yu et al. synthesized the mesoporous ZSM-5/γ-Al2O3 composites with different zeolite contents by using a mechanically mixing method via ball milling for the HDS of 4,6 dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) [1]; the composites were used for supporting Cobalt (Co) and molybdenum (Mo) catalysts. The results revealed that the combination of ZSM-5 with γ-Al2O3 caused to a modified meso‑porous structure for the catalyst in favor of the mass transfer between the reaction species. Moreover, the adjusted acidity of the catalyst by the zeolite had been beneficial for a well dispersion of MoS2 active phases on the support. Yin et al. investigated the sol-gel and mechanical mixing approaches for the synthesis of HY-Al2O3 composite supports for NiMo catalysts in the HDS of diesel fuel [29]. They reported that mechanically mixing method resulted in a better meso‑porosity structure, more acid-content and higher Mo dispersion comparing to the sol-gel approach. Moreover, since the sol-gel method requires materials that are expensive and/or commercially scarce, this approach includes a small chance for the industrialization. Another drawback of sol-gel methods is difficulty separation of the products from the mother liquid. While mechanical mixing methods are very effective and commercially scalable. The creating a hierarchical structure of HY zeolite using Al2O3 to produce an efficient composite support for the ODS catalysts would be attractive while has not been investigated in the previous researches. In addition, vanadium catalysts doped on a suitable support with an adjusted structure can be considerable in the ODS of thiophenic compounds due to its superior activity via enhancing the oxidation reaction by H2O2 through forming V IV − O − O · species [34]. In this work, for the first time, different HY-zeolite/alumina composites with a hierarchical structure were prepared by an extrusion method and used for supporting vanadia catalyst for the ODS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) in the model fuel. The physical mixture of HY-zeolite and Al2O3 powders as the support was also applied for the vanadium impregnation to compare the results with the extruded composite. The influences of alumina/zeolite composition and main effective operation factors were investigated and discussed. The selectivity of the introduced catalyst with the composite support was also evaluated in the ODS of DBT in the presence of indole as a model of nitrogen-containing compounds. In addition to the sulfur compounds, nitrogen-containing compounds are serious pollutants in the fuels which can also have negative impacts on the catalyst in the ODS process [35]. Moreover, during the ODS of fuels, a considerable competition can also be occurred between the oxidation of sulfur and nitrogen-containing compounds on the catalysts active sites. Therefore, indole as a conventional model of nitrogen-containing compounds in real diesel fuel was also added to the model fuel in this work and the simultaneous oxidation of DBT and indole was evaluated. 2 Experimental work 2.1 Materials Iso-octane, toluene, DBT, H2O2 (aqueous solution, 30 wt%), acetonitrile, N-hexadecane, ethyl acetate, ammonium monovanadate were purchased from Merck, Germany. Indole was purchased from Sigma, Germany. HY zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3= 5.3) was provided from Iran Zeolite Co. Boehmite (>99.8%) was provided from Mineral Research Center of Azarshahr, Iran. All materials were utilized without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The support materials used in this work for the catalysts preparation were HY Zeolite-Al2O3 composites (named as HYZ-Al composites) and HY Zeolite for a comparison with the composites. For the composites preparation, an appropriate amount of HY zeolite and boehmite powders (with 4:1, 4:2 and 4:3 dry mass ratio) were kneaded mechanically with a mixer for 30 min to homogenize the size distribution. Then pre-determined amounts of HNO3 solution were gradually added to the dry powders and mixed continually to form a homogenous paste [2]. The paste was subsequently shaped using a homemade extruder as shown in Fig. 1 . Next, the extrudes were dried overnight in an oven at 120 °C and calcined in air at 550 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min for three hours. Then the prepared HYZ-Al were crushed and sieved to the mesh size of 100–120 for vanadium loading. The obtained supports were denoted as HYZ-Al (X) where X is alumina/zeolite dry mass ratio (X = 25, 50, 75). The γ-Al2O3 powder was also synthesized by the calcination of boehmite powder in air at 500 °C with heating rate of 5 °C/min for four hours denoted as Al [36]. The V (10 wt%) were impregnated on the supports using an aqueous solution of ammonium monovanadate at 60 °C for eight hours. Then the temperature increased to 80 °C to evaporate the water. The obtained solids were dried overnight in an oven at 120 °C, and calcined in air atmosphere for 3 h at 450 °C with a 5 °C/min heating rate. 10 wt% loading was chosen as a suitable amount according to the previous research studies [37,38]. Based on the use of HYZ-Al2O3, and HY zeolite as the support, the obtained catalysts were named as V/HYZ-Al, and V/HYZ, respectively. The physical mixing of HY zeolite and alumina was also prepared without using the extruder. The rest steps were the same as described above. This catalyst was nominated as V/HYZ-Al(X)-PM, where X is alumina/zeolite dry mass ratio 2.3 Catalyst characterization The chemical composition of different samples was identified using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis by PW1410 Philips instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) diagrams of the samples were recorded using Philips PW1730 instrument in the range of 5°<2θ<70° with Cu Kα radiation at 30 mA and 40 kV. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined using Bel mini II instrument. Pore volume and specific surface area were calculated using Brunauer - Emmett - Teller (BET) equation. While, the pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett–Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The morphology of the synthesized catalysts was identified by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) analysis using Tescan-VEGA instrument and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis using Philips-EM208S instrument. The elemental composition of the samples was also determined using X-ray energy diffraction spectroscopy (EDS) by means of Sirius device. The types of the vanadium species distributed over the catalyst surface were identified using Visible Ultra-Violent Spectroscopy (UV-vis) analysis by Perkin Elmer Lambda-35 instrument. NH3 Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was performed to evaluate the acidic properties of the samples by means of NanoSORD NS91 devise. 2.4 Catalytic test The model oil was a solution of 1000 ppmw DBT and 400 ppmw indole in a mixture of isooctane and toluene; the volume ratio of isooctane to toluene was 9:1. In a typical run, a three-neck glass batch reactor equipped with a condenser and water bath was fed by adding a certain amount of the catalyst to a mixture of the model oil and extraction solvent; the volume ratio of the model oil per solvent was 2:1. A certain amount of the oxidant (H2O2) was introduced to the reactor after that the reactor temperature reached to the desired value. To analyze the ODS of DBT, a certain amount of the oil sample was taken out from the reactor after 90 min. The concentration of DBT and indole remained in the model fuel was measured by Varian CP-3800 gas chromatography (GC). The VF capillary column was used in the GC equipped with flame ionization detector (FID). The internal standard used in GC analysis was Hexadecane. The Eq. (1) was used to calculate the DBT (and indole) conversions: (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = C 0 − C f C 0 * 100 Where, respectively, C0 and Cf are the initial and final concentration of DBT (or indole). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst The elemental composition of different samples obtained from XRF analysis is presented in Table 1 . It can be seen that the Al/Si ratio of HYZ zeolite was 0.3 which increased to 2.5 for V/HYZ-Al(75) sample. In addition, the vanadium content was very similar to the nominal amounts of 10 wt%, indicating the successful preparation. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of different samples are demonstrated in Fig. 2 . According to the IUPAC classification, the obtained diagram for HYZ was characteristic of type I, related to the micropore materials. However, a small hysteresis loop at high relative pressures indicated the presence of a small amount of mesoporosity [39]. According to IUPAC classification, the obtained isotherm for Al belongs to the type IV which is the characteristic of the mesopore materials [40]. The observed hysteresis loop for the Al sample was assigned to the H1 type, indicating the well-defined pores [39]. The diagrams attained to the HYZ-Al composites revealed the existence of two types of isotherms; Type I was assigned to the micro-pores due to the presence of Y zeolite in the structure, and type IV was assigned to the meso‑pores due to the presence of alumina in the structure. However, with increasing alumina content from 25 to 75, the amount of N2 uptake and the hysteresis loop increased significantly. As shown in Fig. 2, the vanadium impregnation did not change the type of the characteristic isotherms of the supports. However, the amount of nitrogen adsorbed as well as the hysteresis loop was less for the vanadium impregnated samples. The pore size distribution for the different samples is also shown in Fig. 3 . The HYZ sample revealed a very narrow pore size distribution. As expected, the alumina pore size distribution was wider than the Y zeolite and the pore size was larger. The pore size distribution of the prepared HYZ-Al composites also indicated the existence of hierarchical micro and meso‑pores in the structure. It was clear that raising alumina content from 25 to 75, resulted in a remarkable increase in the volume of the porosity. The textural features of the prepared catalysts are given in Table 2 . It can be seen that adding alumina to the zeolite (from 25 to 75) significantly decreased the surface area, although the mesoporous-volume (PVmeso) increased. The HYZ-Al (X) (X = 25, 50, and 75) composite supports exhibited the meso‑pore volume of 0.12 cm3/g, 0.20 cm3/g and 0.26 cm3/g, respectively, which were approximately 3, 5 and 6.5 times greater than the parent zeolite. In order to indicate the surface coverage and micro-pore blockage of the zeolite by the extruding with Al, the micro and meso‑pore volume of the composites were also calculated using the following equations (CPVmicro and CPVmeso, respectively): (2) C P V m i c r o = P V m i c r o o f Z e o l i t e × ( 1 − x ) + P V m i c r o o f A l u m i n a × x (3) C P V m e s o = P V m e s o o f Z e o l i t e × ( 1 − x ) + P V m e s o o f A l u m i n a × x Where x is the mass fraction of alumina in the prepared samples; PVmicro and PVmeso are the actual porosity volumes of the zeolite and alumina obtained from BET analysis as presented in Table 2. The results indicate that CPVmicro of the composites was greater than the actual PVmicro, while CPVmeso was smaller than PVmeso. It can be concluded that by the used extruding approach, the alumina blocks the micro-pores heavily, leading to a significant reduction in the surface area and micro-pore volume. However, the meso‑pore volumes considerably improved by the extruding approach, mainly due to the generation of meso‑pores by alumina particles piling. These larger particle piling pores may be able to significantly accelerate the diffusion of bulky DBT molecules in the ODS process. As shown in Table 2, the loading of vanadium on HYZ and HYZ-Al composites, has been effective in reducing the specific surface area and pore volume due to the loss of porosity being covered by the vanadium species. The SEM images of the parent HY zeolite, alumina, V/HYZ-Al(25), and V/HYZ-A1(50) samples are shown in Fig. 4 . HY zeolite exhibited well defined crystals with a relatively uniform shape and size. SEM images of the V/HYZ-Al(25), and V/HYZ-A1(50) samples showed that a dense layer was formed over the zeolite surface by deposition of alumina particles in the extruded composites. Further investigation by TEM images shown in Fig. 5 , reveals that parts of alumina penetrated into the bulk of the zeolite. It can be seen from Fig. 5b that the crystal structure of the zeolite was influenced by the intrusion of alumina so that the lattice fringes of zeolite were deformed to some extent. In addition, some alumina particles were accumulated over the zeolite surface with an irregular shape. The excess alumina particles can also be accumulated together leading to form larger particle piling pores, which is in accordance with BET results in Table 2. EDX mapping micrographs of V/HYZ-Al(50) are illustrated in Fig. 6 . As seen, vanadium was dispersed uniformly over the support surface. Moreover, the surface vanadium content of V/HYZ-Al(50) was measured by EDX analysis and presented in Table 1. It can be seen that Vanadium content over the surface of V/HYZ-Al(50) was very similar to the bulk content. The acidic properties of the V/HYZ, V/HYZ-Al(25), and V/HYZ-Al(50) catalysts were evaluated with NH3-TPD analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 7 , all the samples exhibited two peaks at 210 and 450 °C, which are respectively related to weak and strong acid sites [41–43]. The lower temperature peak at 210 °C induced by weakly acidic silanol groups distributed over the external surface and/or from the lattice defects. While the high temperature peak at 450 °C is generated, if Al3+ replaces Si4+ in the zeolite framework where the produced negative charge is compensated by H+ [43]. The intensity of both peaks was enhanced in the extruded supported catalysts compared to the V/HYZ sample. Also, the acidity of the composite support increased considerably with increasing the alumina content. Because the alumina has a certain amounts of acidic sites, leading to increase of both weak and strong acidic sites of the composites. For a comparison with extrusion, the NH3-TPD profile of the V/HYZ-Al(25)-PM prepared by physical mixing was also illustrated in Fig. 7. The weak acid sites were higher for V/HYZ-Al(25) comparing to V/HYZ-Al(25)-PM, while the increase in the corresponding strong acid was less. Similar observation was also reported by Guo et al. [41] during the bounding REUSY zeolite with alumina. They have suggested that the acidic feature of alumina reduces energy barrier of H2O, during the composite synthesis by extruding, attacking the tetrahedrally coordinated aluminum in the lattice structure of the zeolite which leads to the destruction of the framework by removing or distorting of Al from the zeolite (dealumination), and increasing weak acid sites. During high pressure extrusion and high temperature calcination in this work, the Al-OH in the alumina can also react with the free Si-OH bond over the zeolite surface leading to generation more strong acid sites [41,43]. Because of a more increment in the weak acid sites, it can be concluded that the increase in the acidic properties of the zeolite by the extrusion in this work was more due to the creation of non-framework aluminum through the dealumination of the zeolite. The obtained results were in agreement with Kong and Liu [44] that reported HZSM-5-alumina composite with 10 wt% alumina exhibited higher acidic density as compared to the parent HZSM-5 zeolite. According to another research study by Wu et al. [45], Bronsted acid density of the alumina bounded Y zeolite was increased. However, Michels et al. [46] stated a decline in the acidic properties of the boehmite-ZSM-5 composite catalyst. The XRD patterns of the samples are displayed in Fig. 8 . In accordance to XRD card: 01-077-1549, The XRD patterns of V/HYZ-Al(25), V/HYZ-Al(50) and V/HYZ-Al(75) revealed the Y zeolite characteristic peaks [12]; however, the intensity of the respected peaks decreased significantly for the composite supported catalysts. This result indicated that the crystallization degree of the HYZ-Al samples decreased through disordering during the composite synthesis [45]. The alumina addition damages the framework of Y zeolite in a way that can embed the extra-framework aluminum species from the boehmite. The reduced crystallinity can also be explained by destructive effects through dealumination and removing tetrahedrally coordinated aluminum from the zeolite framework, as evidenced by NH3-TPD analysis. The XRD pattern of V/HYZ-Al(75) in Fig. 8 revealed the characterization peaks of alumina at 46° and 67.4° In addition, V oxides diffraction peaks were not detected in the XRD patterns because of a well incorporation of V oxide species into the composite or formation of highly dispersed nano-crystals [47]. UV-Vis analysis was used to identify the type of the vanadium species dispersed over the catalyst. The results were illustrated in Fig. 9 . The synthesized catalysts exhibited different peaks in the range of 200–500 nm, indicating the presence of various types of vanadium species on the catalyst structure. For V/HYZ sample, some peaks in the range of 200–280, 280–330 and 330–380 nm can be observed which were respectively associated to the isolated tetrahedral vanadium species inserted in the framework of the support, polymeric non-framework vanadium species dispersed over the external surface area of the support, and octahedral vanadium species [48,49]. However, for HYZ-Al composites, besides the bands at 200–380 nm, new absorption bands at around 380–500 nm were also appeared corresponded to the crystalline V2O5 phase; the area of these bands turned to be higher with increasing the alumina content (from X = 25 to 75) accompanied by a decline in the area of the peaks at lower wave lengths around 200–280 nm. Therefore, the alumina content negatively influenced the dispersion of vanadium because of the formation of V2O5 crystals. This negative effect is due to the possible combination of V species in the meso‑pores over the support. However, the XRD analysis did not detect any crystalline V phase due to their small sizes. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic performance of different prepared samples (V/HYZ, V/HYZ-Al(25), V/HYZ-Al(50), V/HYZ-Al(75), and V/HYZ-Al(50)-PM) has been evaluated in the removal of DBT and indole from the model fuel. The results shown in Fig. 10 , illustrated that the nitrogen compounds were completely eliminated using all the catalysts. This indicated that nitrogen compounds can be oxidized and eliminated faster than DBT due to their higher oxidation reactivity. It can be seen that V/HYZ catalyst showed the lowest DBT conversion (78.0 ± 2%) among all the catalysts. When 25% alumina was introduced into the zeolite, the DBT conversion was significantly enhanced from 78.0 ± 2 to 85.1 ± 1.3%. By increasing alumina content from 25 to 50%, the DBT conversion increased markedly from 85.1 ± 1.3 to 93.3 ± 1.9% at the investigated conditions. Mass transfer limitations are known as the important factors affecting the performance of the zeolite-based catalysts. The catalytic performance of V/HYZ zeolite was mainly restricted by the diffusion resistance for the bulky DBT penetration to the zeolite micro-pores. According to the BET results (Table 2), the meso‑pore volume significantly increased by adding alumina and increasing alumina/zeolite from 25 to 50%. Therefore, the access of bulky DBT molecules to the active sites was improved which enhanced the catalytic ODS efficiency of V/HYZ-Al(50). The lower catalytic activity at the higher alumina/zeolite of 75% can be related to poor dispersion of V active phase on the composite by V2O5 crystals formation according to UV-vis results (Fig. 9). The physical mixing of the zeolite and alumina (V/HYZ-Al(50)-PM) exhibited lower catalytic activity where only 81.5 ± 1.8% of DBT was eliminated. The porosity of V/HYZ-Al(50) and V/HYZ-Al(50)-PM catalysts were schematically illustrated in Fig. 11 . The micro- and meso‑pores in the structure of V/HYZ-Al(50)-PM‏ ‏can separately influence the performance in the removal of DBT without any synergetic effect. In this case, as discussed above, the dispersed V over the alumina meso‑pores may be aggregated to form V2O5 crystals; while the micro-porosity of the HY-zeolite includes difficulty access of bulky DBT to the pores. However, based on the characterization results of V/HYZ-Al(50) composite, interconnecting of zeolite micro-pores by the alumina larger pores during the extrusion procedure and higher V distribution, improved the access of bulky DBT species to the active sites and then increased the ODS efficiency. The stronger acidity of V/HYZ-Al(50) composite detected by NH3-TPD results could be another reason for enhanced oxidation reaction of DBT during the process. In order to determine the effect of the oxidant content on the catalytic performance of the developed V/HYZ-Al(50) composite, desulfurization experiments were performed at different oxidant/(sulfur+nitrogen) molar ratios (named O/(S+N)) of 6, 12 and 18. The results are shown in Fig. 12 . The efficiency of DBT removal improved from 89.8 ± 1.1 to 93.3 ± 1.9% by increasing the O/(S+N) ratio from 6 to 12. However, a further increase in the O/(S+N) amount from 12 to 18 resulted in a decrease of DBT removal. Since the zeolites with a low Si/Al ratio (as HY zeolite) have a hydrophilic feature, a more water introduced to the reaction media through the 30 wt% H2O2 solution as the oxidant, may be easily adsorbed by the composite surface [50], so caused the observed loss in the catalytic activity [5]. Another main effective factor in the ODS process, is the reaction temperature. To determine the effect of temperature, the V/HYZ-Al(50) catalyst performance was evaluated at 40, 50, 60 and 80 °C, and the results are shown in Fig. 13 . The highest removal rate of DBT, which is equivalent to 97.7 ± 1.1%, was achieved at 50 °C. Elevating the temperature from 50 to 80 °C decreased the sulfur removal efficiency from 97.7 ± 1.1 to 72.1 ± 1.0% because that the acceleration of thermal decomposition of H2O2 at higher temperatures which can negatively affect the catalyst performance [51]. The effects of Mcatalyst/Vfuel ratio (g/L) on the DBT conversion by V/HYZ-Al(50) catalyst was also revealed in Fig. 14 . According to the results, in the absence of the catalyst, 51.5 ± 1.7% DBT removal was reached due to the extraction of DBT by the acetonitrile solvent. While after introducing the catalyst with Mcatalyst/Vfuel ratio of 8 g/L, the DBT conversion was improved greatly as 97.7 ± 1.1% of DBT was removed. Completely removal of DBT was reached by increasing the amount of the catalyst to 10 g/L, due to the more available active sites. Further increase in catalyst content caused decrease in DBT removal. The recyclability of the catalyst is one of the most important environmental and economic parameters in the industry. Therefore, the stability and reusability of the V/HYZ-Al(50) catalyst was evaluated. The ODS of the model fuel containing DBT and indole (1000 ppmw DBT and 400 ppmw indole) was performed under the determined optimal conditions by the recycled catalyst three times. After each run, the used catalyst was separated and washed with acetonitrile as extracting solvent at 50 °C for one hour to extract all the hydrocarbons or oxidized product compounds deposited on the surface. Then the solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The recycled catalyst was used for the next run at the same conditions. The obtained results are shown in Fig. 15 . It can be seen that the DBT conversion decreased from 100 ± 1.4% to 96.4 ± 1.7% after four consecutive runs, revealing a high stability and recyclability potential for the presented V/HYZ-Al(50) catalyst in the ODS process. The catalytic performance of V/HYZ-Al(50) was compared with some previous published results of ODS using zeolite-based or vanadium containing catalysts illustrated in Table 3 . The used extrusion as a cost effective and scalable method, as well as the high catalytic ability for completely removal of DBT at mild conditions were the main advantages of the suggested catalyst in this work compared to the similar previous catalysts in the literatures. 4 Conclusion The micro/meso‑ porous structure of the developed zeolite-alumina composite in this work was attractive to have a supported catalyst with proper modified characteristics for the ODS of DBT. The effects of alumina/zeolite ratio on the textural properties, acidity, vanadium dispersion, and possible destructions of the zeolite framework were investigated and discussed. In order to adjust the composite porosity and vanadium distribution, the alumina/zeolite ratio should be controlled. The hierarchical micro/meso‑porosity, high surface area and pore volume, and well dispersion of the impregnated vanadium active phases were verified by different analysis for the suggested V/HYZ-Al (50) catalyst. Also, the applied extrusion method regulated the useful acidity of the composite for an efficient DBT removal. The proposed V/HYZ-Al(50) catalyst in this work showed a high recyclability in the recycling study. Therefore, a beneficial commercial application for this catalyst can be predicte. coredata.dc:description: Despite the advantages of zeolite catalysts/carriers, the small pore size of HY zeolite causes diffusion limitations especially for bulky refractory sulfur compounds in oxidative desulfurization (ODS) of fuels. To overcome this restriction, extruded HY-zeolite/Alumina composites containing both micro and meso‑pores were successfully synthesized and used as an attractive carrier for the vanadium dispersion. Insights about the interactions between zeolite and alumina and their effects on the vanadium impregnation were given implementing different analysis approaches; BET, SEM-EDX, TEM, NH3-TPD, and UV-vis. Alumina particle piling created meso‑pores in the composites providing a positive impact on the ODS of bulky dibenzothiophene (DBT). Comparing to physical mixing of the alumina and zeolite, the extrusion approach notably enhanced the weak acid sites due to the removal/distorting tetrahedrally coordinated Al from the zeolite framework. A less increase in the strong acid sites was also resulted from the reaction of Al-OH in the alumina with the free Si-OH over the zeolite. The proposed catalyst (V/HYZ-Al(alumina/zeolite ratio=50%) exhibited an excellent DBT removal so that 1000 ppmw of DBT was eliminated completely under the optimal investigated conditions (T = 50 °C, O/(S+N)=12 mol/mol, time=90 min, Mcatalyst/Vfuel=10 g/L). The catalyst recyclability was proved to be acceptable during four examined successive ODS cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Supported vanadium oxide catalyst over HY-zeolite-alumina composite fabricated by extrusion for oxidative desulfurization of dibenzothiophene
